ABSTRACT

02 August 2010
Proposal Number: 1019663
Institution: Columbia University, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory
PI: P. Ljunggren
Co-PI: D. Goldberg

The proposal requests one Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment (SSSE) item for the R/V MARCUS LANGSETH operated by Columbia University, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO); namely overhaul of the vessel?s seismic compressors. Funding of this item will greatly enhance science support capability and reliability.


Broader Impacts: The LANGSETH supports federally funded scientific research throughout the world?s oceans to expand human knowledge of the ocean environment and is the only 3D seismic vessel in the academic fleet. During operations, the vessel routinely exposes graduate and undergraduate students to seagoing oceanography through real-time satellite connectivity from ship to shore, and open house events. The LANGSETH is scheduled to complete over 75 NSF sponsored days in 2010.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The R/V Marcus G. Langseth has two engine rooms on the vessel. One engine room contains the main ship engines that propel it through the ocean. The Langseth is also outfitted with two large 5-stage air compressors that are driven by two Caterpillar engines and are capable of producing 2000psi air to support the seismic operations.  This air supply is used to charge sound sources in our four sound source arrays that are towed behind the ship and fired at typically ~15 sec intervals. When activated, the gun chambers open and the high pressure air rushes out creating a low frequency pulse that penetrates the ocean bottom. These pulses are reflected by structures in sub-seafloor and received by the ship's towed hydrophones (listening devices). These reflections are combined by scientists to develop images of the earth's structure deep below the seafloor (10-30km).

 This award funded maintenance activities on the ariel compressors that are driven by the Caterpillar engines that were required after an inspection of the five stages of each air compressor were opened and inspected. It was discovered that major components beyond the planned maintenance had to be either replaced or reconditioned.   These funds were also used for additional work that was required for overhauling two critical Fisher valves that control airflow from compressors.
